The $380 and $391 puts have negative gains because they are out-of-the-money options and the underlying stock price will not hit the strike price, resulting in no payout and a loss of the premium paid. The $391 calls have negative gains because they are also out-of-the-money options and will not result in a payout. The $396 calls and puts have positive gains because the underlying stock price is above the strike price, resulting in a payout.

data.sampled:
90.7708861.28 [$5.48 x 100 + ($180 - $167.5) x 100 - $5.6 x 100 - ($180 - $192.5) x 100 - $10.33 x 100 -$10.9 x 100= $1,682.00000, -$499.840000]
Note: To calculate the breakeven stock price, you need to add the net credit received from the sale of call options to the cost of the put options purchased and subtract the negative cost of buying the calls and the put options sold, and then add any negative credit received from selling option premium to this number. In this case, the credit received from selling premium for the $167.5 strike price put and for the $192.5 strike price call was not specified, but assuming that it is zero, the total net credit (or fee) for transaction is -$499.840000 resulting in a total premium of -$499.840000
If sold premium for $167.5 strike price put is higher than $5.48 then the breakeven price will be higher than 90.770886 and if sold premium for $192.5 strike price call is lower than $5.6 then the breakeven price will be lower than 90.770886. Also, the amount of credit can change the breakeven stock price. If it's higher than $0 then the breakeven price will be lower than $90.7
